description:
Lipomyces doorenjongii is a species of yeast that belongs to the genus Lipomyces. It was first isolated from soil samples collected in Dooren, Belgium.

Lipomyces doorenjongii is a lipid-accumulating yeast, meaning it has the ability to store large amounts of lipids or fats within its cells. This property makes it of interest for potential industrial applications, such as the production of biodiesel or other oleochemicals.

Morphologically, Lipomyces doorenjongii forms round to oval-shaped cells that can reproduce by budding. The species is capable of assimilating a variety of carbon sources, including glucose, sucrose, and other sugars.

Genetically, Lipomyces doorenjongii has been studied and its genome sequence has been determined, providing insights into the genetic mechanisms underlying its lipid accumulation capabilities.

Overall, Lipomyces doorenjongii is a unique yeast species with potential biotechnological applications due to its ability to accumulate significant amounts of lipids within its cells.
